In the previous definition, the small Schröder numbers were defined as:

s₀ = 1, s₁ = 1, s₂ = 1, s₃ = 3...
This does not match the sequence listed in OEIS A006318. Moreover, this definition makes it difficult to correctly write the generating function for the small Schröder numbers. Therefore, we have revised the definition of the small Schröder numbers and derived their generating function accordingly,#33817 hoping it can be merged into mathlib as soon as possible.
I left various suggestions yesterday you haven't addressed yet.

Hello, I am the author and submitter of this PR. Thank you for your feedback and suggestions. We have adopted your advice regarding the complexity of the proof for smallSchroder_succ and have refactored that part accordingly.

As for the other suggestions—such as changing certain items to antidiagonal—we have decided to keep the current versions. These formulations have already passed mathlib’s review in earlier contributions and were merged into the codebase.

For instance, in largeSchroder: 

largeSchroder (n + 1) = largeSchroder n + ∑ i ≤ n, largeSchroder i * largeSchroder (n - i)

Since the existing style is consistent with what has been accepted before, we believe it is appropriate to retain them as they are.

Mathlib code isn't static, it doesn't just get merged and stay like that forever. The reason I mention antidiagonalis that it provides in my view a more natural spelling of "pairs adding up to n", which conveniently avoids (or at least hides) nat subtraction.
I mean, if we have the API, why not use it

Violeta Hernández said:

I mean, if we have the API, why not use it

We've added a new theorem at the end of the smallSchroder

theorem smallSchroder_succ_add_smallSchroder (n : ℕ) :
    smallSchroder (n + 1) + smallSchroder n =
      2 * ∑ ij ∈ antidiagonal n, smallSchroder ij.1 * smallSchroder ij.2 := by sorry
